title.narrative: Envelope 1: Provision of shelter support and integrated services for vulnerable populations in northwest Syria

description.narrative:
Under this project, IOM proposes to provide dignified shelter, with complementary infrastructure, Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), and Protection services in 12 informal sites and surrounding locations in Idleb, targeting 13,932 beneficiaries. In addition, IOM proposes to continue CCCM service provision in 10 IOM-managed Planned Camps (PCs) in Idleb and Aleppo to ensure the successful completion of the dignified shelter intervention under SCHF-funded project-20631. In total, 42,344 beneficiaries will be supported.
In the 12 informal sites in Idleb, IOM, through its Implementing Partner (IP) IYD, proposes to install 2,020 Transitional Dignified Shelters (TDS). The following informal sites in Dana and Maaret Tamsrin sub-districts will be targeted: Muzun, Ayadi, Alsadka Alkhayri, Rieayat Altufula, Halab Alshahba-2, Al-Harraqat, Al Khald, Harbnush, Sinjar, Dalama, Al Huda and Ehsan. Locations were selected based on the availability of Housing, Land and Property (HLP) documentation, flood/wind vulnerability, tent coverage, beneficiary preference, and acute needs. To ensure dignified living conditions, the shelter intervention will be complemented by infrastructure upgrades, WASH, CCCM, and Protection services. The size of the TDS is 26 m2, including kitchen and WASH facilities, as well as an additional 10 m2 open outdoor area. The TDS will be built on a concrete slab and comprise of a steel frame, lockable doors, PVC windows, sandwich panel walls and roof, and a solar lighting system. The TDS will be locally produced to the greatest extent possible and installed through a cash-for-work modality.
IOM’s proposed shelter design is designed to last over 10 years, offering good insulation and ventilation, a living space in line with Sphere standards (average household of 5 people allows for 5.2m2/person), an adaptable outdoor space, a private WASH and cooking area and lockable doors, providing increased dignity and safety to affected populations.
Under the proposed complementary WASH component, IOM and its IP (IYD) will, in coordination with other response actors, engage in the provision of water trucking or water networks, the construction and/or maintenance of household-level sewer networks, desludging, solid waste management, hygiene promotion and hygiene kit distributions.
Under the proposed protection component, IOM and Syria Relief, or an alternative SCHF-approved Protection partner, will provide integrated protection services in all 12 sites targeted with dignified shelter support, as well as adjacent communities, including in Qourqueena sub-district, by establishing six Protection help desks and three outreach teams. The protection component will be closely integrated with the other proposed sectors, including training in Safe Identification and Referral (SIR), Gender-Based Violence (GBV) safety audits, and disability inclusion programming.
Contributing to an integrated approach to providing dignified shelters in informal sites, IOM’s CCCM team, which has been working closely with IOM’s shelter team to identify/assess the 12 informal sites, proposes to support local governance structures, conduct trainings on Sphere standards, CCCM, and implement fire risk mitigation activities using mobile teams. IOM also proposes to continue camp management activities in the 10 IOM-managed PCs, which are currently funded by SCHF under project-20631, to install dignified shelters. Building on past CERF and SCHF-funded projects and in line with the Dignified Shelter strategy, IOM proposes to continue implementing CCCM activities in the 10 PCs for three months (October to December 2022) following the approval of the NCE for the current project. Following the installation of the shelters, the CCCM team will be providing care and maintenance trainings, ensuring the sustainability of the project. IOM will also use this period to execute a phase-out plan from the camps.
